issues.description: The problem UML (and the solution) expects a Stock method named emptyStock(), but the template repository's Stock class provides a method named clearInventory() instead. This name/signature mismatch between the problem description and the template will confuse students about which method to use or implement and may cause tests or the reference solution to fail if they expect emptyStock().
issues.suggested_fix: Make the template Stock API match the problem statement and solution. Rename the template method clearInventory() to emptyStock() (keeping it public and void with no parameters), or update the problem statement/UML to reference clearInventory() instead. Preferably rename in the template so method name matches the UML and solution.

issues.description: The problem statement and the solution repository use a Stock method named emptyStock() to clear the inventory, but the template repository names this same operation clearInventory(). This naming divergence for the same conceptual operation (clearing/emptying the stock) creates an unnecessary mapping burden: students reading the UML/problem expect emptyStock(), will look for that in the starter code but find clearInventory(), and may be confused about which method to call or implement.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the method name across artifacts. Rename the template method clearInventory() to emptyStock() (or add a delegating emptyStock() method that calls clearInventory()) so the starter code matches the UML/problem statement and the solution. This preserves the intended API and reduces student confusion.
